hmmm... I don't use the textui, but this behavior seems a little bass
ackwards to me. Shouldn't there at least be an option to turn it on if you
want to see it?

-----Original Message-----
From: Thomas SMETS [mailto:tsmets@...]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 6:01 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Method assertEquals


Becoze U are bloody using the bloody junit.textui.TestRunner class
If you did RTFM you'd know that the message comes in the GUI environment.
 
Use the junit.swingui.TestRunner or the junit.ui.TestRunner for an AWT GUI.
 
Thomas,
 
 
 

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Sriram  <mailto:ssaeenat@...> Anandraj 
To: junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com>  
Sent: Saturday, December 08, 2001 2:33 AM
Subject: [junit] Method assertEquals


Assert.assertEquals("Message", expected, actual);

Why is that the "Message"  not getting printed on the standard output ??
Instead a dot is printed.
Then what's the purpose of the 1'st argument for the above method ?

-Sriram
